abstract.p: Prof Mark Edmond Clark letter comments on July 7 article on report by General Accounting Office that US programs to assist Bosnia have been hindered because of corruption among Bosnians; says West's misreading of Bosnian society may be more genuine cause of failure to bring change about

block.p: A General Accounting Office report concludes that the United States' programs to assist Bosnia have been hindered because of corruption among the Bosnians (news article, July 7). Yet the West's misreading of Bosnian society may be a more genuine cause for the failure to bring change about.

A General Accounting Office report concludes that the United States' programs to assist Bosnia have been hindered because of corruption among the Bosnians (news article, July 7). Yet the West's misreading of Bosnian society may be a more genuine cause for the failure to bring change about.

Policy analysts may recognize that Bosnia's governing bodies and business systems are mired in a corrupt, bureaucratic style left over from its Communist past. But they must also accept that Bosnia's bewildering political, economic and social structures cannot be fathomed by viewing them through a Western prism.

Only after these structures have been fully examined and delineated can the rebuilding of Bosnia get under way, guided by a policy better suited for its society and more coherent than the current one.
MARK EDMOND CLARK New York, July 11, 2000
The writer is a visiting professor of sociology at the University of Banja Luka.
